assets.title: Dean Barker admits to 'hard learnings' as capsize in America's Cup test boat revealed
assets.intro: Dean Barker has admitted to some "hard learnings" as video emerges of his America's Cup test boat capsizing during training in Florida.
assets.alt_intro: Phenomenal speed countered by capsize as new video shows complexities and potential of radical design.
assets.body:
Dean Barker has admitted to some "hard learnings" as video emerges of his America's Cup test boat capsizing during training in Florida.

Barker is at the helm of the powerful challenge of the New York Yacht Club and says they have been making exciting progress with their scaled-down test boat at their winter training camp in the Sunshine State.

But it hasn't been without it's dramas as they work through the complexities of the radical new design for Auckland 2021 where the 36th America's Cup will feature 75-foot foiling monoulls.

Kiwi Barker, who was at the forefront of foiling's introduction to the Cup skippering Team New Zealand's 2013 challenge in San Francisco and then heading Japan's challenge on smaller foiling catamarans at Bermuda 2017, predicts "exciting action" for Auckland based on his experiences in Florida.

READ MORE:
* Burling, Tuke eager for foiling around world
* Dennis Conner's America's Cup reality check
* Dutch reaffirm America's Cup commitment
* Spithill: Why I felt sorry for Dean Barker​​

"The dynamic of it is very different from the catamarans which is a great challenge, and from a competitive standpoint you enjoy the challenge of learning what the boat is all about and how it behaves and all the things that it likes to do and doesn't like to do," Barker said in an American Magic video released on Wednesday.

"You learn the hard way at times but it's also very rewarding when things start to come together.

"Our speeds are pretty phenomenal and I think with the AC75, we're going to see some pretty exciting action. That's still a ways away but we're looking toward getting there eventually."

Escaping the American winter at their Rhode Island base to sail in the sunny south at Pensacola has allowed American Magic to get some real momentum to the famous New York club's return to Cup racing.

"This has been a new class, a very new concept, and we've obviously got a huge list of things to work our way through," Barker said.

"Pretty much every day there's something to learn and so it's really valuable for the team as a whole to be able to go through the process of getting the boat on the water every day. We get the good part to be able to sail it."

Andrew Campbell, who joined American Magic from the now defunct Oracle Team USA to stay involved in the Cup game, talked up the Florida conditions.

"Pensacola has completely exceeded expectations," Campbell said.

"Flat water, plenty of breeze, hasn't been too cold and people are good here. They've treated us really well. It's just a nice big racetrack where we can stretch out and do everything we need to do testing wise but it's challenging enough that it keeps us keep us on our toes. We couldn't be any happier to be here.

"The 38 (test boat) is our best shot at getting a feel for what the pain points are going to be around the racetrack.

"We're trying to put ourselves under pressure every day to make sure that we're learning the hard points of sail and the hard corners, so this boat been a great tool for that."

American Magic are due to relocate to Rhode Island later in May.

images.caption: "You learn the hard way at times," Dean Barker says after his America's Cup test boat capsized.
New Zealand sailor Dean Barker at the wheel of American Magic's test boat.
American Magic are happy with the progress made testing design tweaks for their 2021 America's Cup challenge.

videos.caption: Dean Barker talks up potential of new design but doesn't shy away from capsize problems.

assets.title: Chris Hipkins hits out at anti-vaxxers as 'pro-plague'
assets.intro: Education Minister Chris Hipkins has said anti-vaxxers are "pro-plague" as pleas are made to parents to vaccinate their children amid a measles outbreak.
assets.alt_intro: Education Minister hits out at parents who won't immunise their children amid a measles outbreak.
assets.body:
Education Minister Chris Hipkins has said anti-vaxxers are "pro-plague" as pleas are made to parents to vaccinate their children amid a measles outbreak.

In Northland, the district health board has asked that schools consider telling unimmunised children to stay at home.  The immunisation rate in the region is about 86 per cent.

"Those people who are anti-vaccination are pro plague. It is a ridiculous position, it is not based on science," he said.

"There are very good reasons why we require a certain level of the population to be immunised,so we are not susceptible to massive outbreaks and where those people arguing against it on non-science are basically irresponsible."

READ MORE:
* Anti-vaxxers 'delusional' and 'dangerous'
* 'I now view anti-vaxxers as sort of a cult'

The DHB needed to step up in terms of their responsibility to ensure that the Northland population does have sufficient levels of immunisation and clearly there was an issue there, he said.

"I don't believe that kids should be denied their right to an education, particularly if it's a conscious choice by their parents not to immunise. These are the kids who most deserve to learn about science.

"Kids should not be excluded from their education because their parents are pro-plague."

When Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern was asked about Hipkins pro-plague comment, she said she could see why he felt strongly about it.

"Our sentiment and sense of feeling on this is exactly the same. We have modern medicine to try and protect kids from illnesses that can cause grave damage, even death, we should use it."

"I think the minister is making the point that if you don't vaccinate, you put others at risk and that's unfortunately true."

When asked if the kids should be kept away from school she said that was not the way to try and protect children.

"We want them all to be in school. Ultimately the best protection is vaccination. We have got to make sure that DHBs are focused on reaching as many children as possible.

"One of the unfortunate things I feel like I've seen over the last couple of years is this misinformation. Parents want to do the best by their kids but when there is so much false information that vaccines aren't safe, that's incredibly damaging.

"Parents I just encourage you please vaccinate your children, there are so many horror stories out there. It is the best protection we can provide."

Health Minister DavidClark said anti-vaxxers needed to be challenged and he had a strong view that people need to get vaccinations.

"I think children should not be punished for the decisions of their parents. Those children in particular need access to science probably more than most.

"I do have serious concerns with people that put others at risk … the science is very clear about the benefits of vaccination and some of these diseases are deadly."

Northland DHB needed to do better with its immunisation rates and he wants to see a plan from them that they will lift rates.

"It alarms me when I hear stories of 200 kids at a school are not being immunised."

He said keeping kids at home was something that might be reserved for an outbreak.

He had been advised the two recent cases in Northland had come in from overseas and were not related to the New Zealand cases already.

"It does not take away from the seriousness that we lift our immunisation rates."

images.caption: Education Minister Chris Hipkins' comments were backed by PM Jacinda Ardern.

videos.caption: Education Minister Chris Hipkins calls anti-vaxxer parents "pro-plague".
